name: Toad-headed Agama
description: Its inconspicuous brown-gray coloration blends perfectly with sandy environments. Another adaptation for desert life is its slender toes with rows of projections aiding movement on sand. It has a distinctive large, dorsally flattened head.
food_note: Plant parts, insects (beetles), spiders, rarely smaller lizards and desert plant flowers
image_alt: Toad-headed agama, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Body length 22–24 cm, half of which is the tail; weight up to 55 g
attractions: When threatened, it escapes by rapidly burrowing into the sand with lateral body vibrations.
breeding: Records show these agamas appeared at the zoo in 1957, 1974, and 2011 (subspecies unspecified). In 2006, the zoo briefly kept the nominate subspecies P. m. mystaceus, and since 2011, the subspecies P. m. galli has been bred, producing 14 offspring so far.
